Dear Cody Akers:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & R 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction, prevention;
Section prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description Rule 159. (1) A Child Caring Institution, including private secure
juvenile justice facilities, shall establish a process improvement
and restraint reduction/elimination plan that:
(5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth’s behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth’s
treatment plan.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/27/2024, while in restraints, Staff 1 pushed his elbow into
Youth A's neck and kept his elbow in Staff 1's neck for several
seconds. Youth A could not breathe during this incident. Multiple
staff contest the allegations made by Youth A.
Investigation Staff 8 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/30/2024. She reported being notified about the restraint of Youth
A late on 4/27/24 and went back to the facility on 4/28/24 to read
the reception rights report. She reported having nothing more to
add to the allegations except Youth A was assessed by nursing
staff on 4/28/24.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
4/30/2024 and again face-to-face at the facility on 5/1/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A reported getting into
an argument with Youth B which “almost escalated into a physical
confrontation”. Youth A reported going to his room and Staff 2 and
Staff 3 called for “backup”. When Staff 1 showed up Youth A tried
to shut the door to his room, but Staff 1 put his foot in the way
causing the door to stay open. Youth A reported telling Staff 1 to
go away, but Staff 1 refused to move. Youth A reported “slightly”
pushing Staff 1 and Staff 1 responding with “don’t do that”. Youth
A reported pushing Staff 1 again and this time Staff 1 pushed
Youth A to the floor at which time Youth A began to punch Staff 1
2

a few times. Staff 1 charged at Youth A and placed Youth A in a
restraint (Youth A was unclear and unsure of the chain of events
at this point). Youth A reported Staff 1 grabbed Youth A’s arms
and had Staff 1’s knees and legs so Youth A could not move.
Youth A reported getting his right hand free and punching Staff 1
again in the face several times. Youth A reported he attacked Staff
1 in an effort to get Staff 1 off of Youth A. Youth A reported not
showing any violence and denied hitting the mirror or wall, but just
“cooling off” prior to Staff 1 showing up and blocking Youth A’s
door. Youth A reported Staff 2 and Staff 4 helped Staff 1 with the
restraint but is unsure of other staff involved. Youth A reported
when Staff 1 was holding Youth A on the ground, Staff 1 put his
elbow on Youth A’s neck above the collar bone and on the left
side of Youth A’s neck. Staff 1 had his elbow on Youth A’s neck
for 2-seconds and Youth A was making noises like Youth A was
unable to breath. Youth A reported not getting any oxygen and
showed the position of Staff 1’s elbow as being on the left side of
Youth A’s neck. Youth A changed the story of the incident and
reported, not fighting the restraint because Staff 1 was pushing so
hard that Youth A could not move. Youth A was unable to clarify
why the story changed.
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were interviewed face-to-
face at the facility on 5/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. Both reported being aware of the allegations and believe
Youth A has been struggling emotionally since the permanency
plan for Youth A has been changed. They reported Staff 1 does
not normally work on the pod Youth A is placed and only
responded when a call for support was made by Staff 2 and Staff
3. They reported Youth A is receiving enhanced services which
involves an increase in individual therapy sessions, more team
meetings to process ways to support Youth A, medication for
emotional regulation, increased well-being checks, and one-on-
one supervision if necessary. They reported information is passed
between shifts in regard to Youth A’s behavior along with shift
notes to ensure oncoming staff are aware of any possible issues.
They reported Youth A presented with three specific different
stories to the State Recipient Rights individual. Neither,
Administrator 1 nor Administrator 2 had any firsthand information
about the incident.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/1/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported being present
during the incident. He reported Youth A got into a disagreement
with Youth B resulting in Youth A becoming escalated and going
in and out of Youth A’s room for a quarter of an hour. Finally,
3

Youth A went into Youth A’s room and Staff 2 heard what sounded
like Youth A throwing things and kicking the door. After trying to
deescalate Youth A and being unsuccessful, Staff 2 called for
support. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 went to Youth A’s doorway and
Staff 1 and Youth A spent some time talking. Youth A then
“lunged” at Staff 1 causing Staff 1 to block then hold Youth A’s
arms and redirect Youth A, “bringing Youth A to the floor”. Staff 2
moved to help with the restraint and was told to hold Youth A’s
legs. Staff 2 reported Youth A was trying to kick Staff 2, so Staff 2
adjusted his hold on Youth A’s legs. Staff 2 denied observing
Youth A punch Staff 1 and never observed Staff 1’s arms or hands
near Youth A’s neck. Staff 2 reaffirmed this because he was
“monitoring and watching everything”. Staff 2 reported Youth A
was thrashing around and yelling at Staff 1. Staff 2 reported Staff
1 was “very professional and good” with the restraint and
interactions with Youth A. Youth A never complained of any
injuries or being unable to breath during the incident or after the
restraint. Staff 2 reported Youth A was repositioned during the
restraint because Youth A was too close to the bed and other staff
were unable to reach in order to support the restraint. Staff 2 was
unsure who the other staff were who came to support them. A
nursing staff (unidentified) was present and after releasing Youth
A, this nursing staff asked how Youth A was doing.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B
reported being present during the restraint of Youth A. Youth B
reported observing “choking and stuff” with Youth A during the
restraint. Youth B gave an example of the choking and placed
both of Youth B’s hand around Youth B’s throat in a choking
manner. Youth B reported he walked to the doorway of Youth A’s
bedroom where the restraint was taking place so Youth B could
watch and make sure staff “did not lie” about the restraint. Youth B
reported Youth A was trying to get Staff 1 off of Youth A and
Youth A told Staff 1 that Youth A would get Staff 1 when Youth A
is released from the program.
Therapist was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
Youth A has been doing well in the program over the past few
weeks but with the upcoming termination of his parent’s parental
rights, Youth A is grieving this loss. She reported speaking to
Youth A about the restraint in this allegation and having Youth A
change the story several times. Youth A reported hitting and
punching the walls in Youth A’s room but later told Therapist
Youth A did not hit or punch any walls. Youth A first told Therapist
4

Youth A took a swing at Staff 1 but later the story changed to
Youth A being charged by Staff 1. Youth A informed Therapist that
Youth A didn’t resist Staff 1 before or during the restraint but then
reported to Therapist Youth A punched Staff 1 four times. Youth A
informed Therapist that Youth A was scared and unable to breath
for 15-seconds when being choked by Staff 1. Therapist reported
Youth A’s story about the restraint changed and Youth A told
Therapist, Staff 1 pushed Youth A to the ground while kicking
Youth A and choking Youth A. Therapist reported being confused
how Youth A could have all three of these things happened at the
same time. Therapist reported being concerned about Youth A’s
history of lying to authorities with no sign of remorse.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/1/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 1 reported working
on a different unit the day of the incident with Youth A when he
received a call for support from the unit containing Youth A. When
he walked onto the unit, Staff 1 noticed Youth B, Staff 2, and Staff
3 all standing near Youth A’s bedroom door. Staff 1 reported
taking Staff 3 aside and asking what was occurring. Staff 3
informed Staff 1, Youth A was in Youth A’s room punching a
mirror and Youth A’ hands were bleeding. Staff 1 reported walking
to Youth A’s bedroom door, opening the door, and calling for
Youth A. Youth A started heading towards the door and was
cursing and yelling before trying to push Staff 1 out of the
doorway. Staff 1 reported he told Youth A, that Staff 1 can’t leave
Youth A alone and Staff 1 needed Youth A to step out of the
bedroom. Staff 1 reported Youth A kept pushing Staff 1 and Staff
1 kept informing Youth A that Staff 1 could not leave Youth A
alone in the room because of Youth A’s behaviors. Staff 1 blocked
the door and would not let Youth A shut the door. When Youth A
was able to shut the door, Staff 1 would open the door again. Staff
1 reported the second time he was able to open the door, Youth A
pushed Staff 1 and ‘tried to hit” Staff 1. Staff 2 and Staff 3 were
standing behind Staff 1 and Staff 1 reported feeling comfortable
enough (with Staff 2 and Staff 3’s support) to start a restraint. Staff
1 reported Staff 2, Staff 3, and Youth B were all standing in the
room when the restraint began. Youth B kept walking in and out of
the bedroom. Youth A was able to punch Staff 1 a couple of times
before Staff 1 got behind Youth A and started a standing hold.
Staff 1 was unclear how both Staff 1 and Youth A ended up on the
ground but once on the ground Staff 1 had a hold of Youth A’s
wrists while holding them above Youth A’s head. Staff 1 reported
kneeling on the left side of Youth A so his weight was not on
Youth A who was laying on Youth A’s back. Staff 2 assisted by
holding Youth A’s legs while Staff 3 called for “show” (assistance
5

with a restraint). Staff 1 reported other staff (unknown to Staff 1)
came to assist and he switched out with an unidentified staff
(Nursing tech 1). Prior to Staff 1 leaving the pod, the other staff let
Youth A out of the restraint and Youth A tried to push Staff 1 (who
was leaving) and Staff 1 left through the classroom door to avoid
further interaction with Youth A. Staff 1 reported needing to get off
the pod so his presence was not triggering Youth A. Staff 1 denied
his elbows or hands were near Youth A’s neck at any time during
the restraint.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 5/1/2024 in collaboration
with MDHHS worker. Staff 3 reported being present during the
incident. She remembered the argument between Youth A and
Youth B before Youth A asked to go to Youth A’s room to sleep.
After telling Youth A it was alright to go to the room, Staff 3 heard
loud banging noises coming from Youth A’s room. Staff 3 checked
on Youth A who told Staff 3 to “get the fuck out” of Youth A’s
room. Staff 3 noticed Youth A's knuckles bleeding and Staff 3 told
Staff 2 to call for support. Staff 3 didn’t believe herself and Staff 2
would have been successful in trying to restrain Youth A, if
needed. Staff 3 reported Staff 1 came onto the pod and went to
Youth A’s doorway. Youth A and Staff 1 went back and forth for
about half a minute about how Staff 1 couldn’t leave Youth A
alone in the room because of safety concerns. Youth A finally took
a swing at Staff 1 who initiated a one person standing restraint.
Staff 3 was unsure if Youth A and Staff 1 fell to the ground or if
Staff 1 took Youth A to the ground because Youth A kept fighting.
Staff 3 reported Staff 2 took hold of Youth A’s legs once on the
ground, Staff 3 believed Staff 1 was on the side of Youth A and
holding Youth A’s wrists. Staff 3 denied observing Staff 1’s arms
or hands near Youth A’s neck area. Staff 3 denied ever hearing
Youth A say Youth A could not breath and following the restraint,
Staff 3 had interactions with Youth A who never said anything
about not being able to breath. Staff 3 reported Youth B never
came into the bedroom during the restraint but may have looked
into the room. Staff 3 reported 6 to 8 other staff (unknown to Staff
3) showed up for the “show” and she believes there were 1 or 2
nursing staff (unknown to Staff 3) present for the “show”. She was
unable to identify who the specific staff were that responded to the
“show”. Staff 3 had no concerns about the techniques used by
Staff 1 and believed they were appropriate and taught by the
facility.
Nursing Tech 1 was interviewed via phone on 5/1/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported responding to
the “show” and arriving at the end of the restraint. She reported
6

swapping out with Staff 1 and reported there were two staff
(unidentified) holding Youth A’s arms and one staff (unidentified)
holding Youth A's legs. Once released from the hold, Youth A
began to target Staff 1 but calmed down once Staff 1 left the pod.
Nursing Tech 1 reported she normally works with the older youth
and only responded to the “show” as the reason she was on the
pod. She reported not observing Staff 1’s arms or hands near the
neck of Youth A and having no concerns with the restraint she
observed.
Staff 5 was interviewed via phone on 5/16/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported responding to
an assistance call and when he arrived, he observed Youth A in a
supine position with three staff (Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 4)
engaged in the 3-person restraint hold. Staff 5 reported swapping
out with a staff (unidentified by Staff 5) who was holding Youth A’s
right arm and after approximately 3 to 4 minutes after Staff 5
engaged, Youth A was released. Staff 5 reported Youth A never
complained about not being able to breath or being hurt during or
after the restraint. Staff 5 reported once released Youth A, began
walking around the unit “body checking” staff. Staff 5 reported
being trained in the approved restraint techniques used at the
facility and normally works on the adult unit.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on 5/16/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being one of
the first staff to respond to the assistance call and when entering
the area observed Staff 1 (holding arms) and Staff 2 (holding legs)
engaged in the supine restraint of Youth A. She reported holding
Youth A’s left arm after relieving Staff 1 who was holding both
arms. Youth A never said anything about struggling to breath or
that his neck hurt. Staff 4 reported never observing any staff put
any pressure on Youth A’s neck or near Youth A’s neck. She
reported being relieved by another staff but was unable to identify
who this staff was. She reported being trained in the appropriate
behavior management techniques and normally works in the
adolescent hospitalization unit.
Documents Reviewed:
Residential Adolescent Restraint Form dated 4/29/24
authored by Staff 6. This document outlines the restraint of
Youth A that took place on 4/27/24. It is also documented on this
form that the document has been corrected from 4/29/24 to
4/27/24. It is documented that the restraint took place from 22:15
to 22:23 and involved the following staff: Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3,
Staff 4, Staff 5, and Nursing Tech 1. It documented the justification
7

for the restraint was Youth A’s self-harm and harm to others. The
narrative of the restraint matches what interviewed staff
presented. It is documented that a physical check of Youth A was
completed.
Progress Note authored by Nurse 1 dated 4/28/24 for Youth A.
This document outlines the assessment completed by Nurse 1 on
Youth A following the restraint of Youth A on 4/27/24. It is
documented the unit staff (unidentified) called Nurse 1 to do an
assessment because Youth A was complaining of injuries
sustained during the physical management. It is documented that
there were “3 small 3 cm red spots on the right side of Youth A’s
chin” and Youth A is documented that it was painful to “palpation”.
Youth A reported pain on Youth A’s right clavicle, but no bruising
was assessed. Nurse 1 provided PRN Tylenol 650 mg and Atarax
50 mg for pain and anxiety.
CRS Care Provider Progress Notes authored by Staff 2 dated
4/27/24. This document outlines Youth A displayed behavioral
concerns during the shift noted as physical aggression and self-
injurious behavior resulting in a physical restraint. The physical
restraint is addressed, and the description matches the incident
report and information given by staff interviewed.
Lotus Incident Report dated 4/28/24 with no known author.
This document outlines the behaviors occurring prior to the
restraint of Youth A on 4/27/24. There is also a description of
attempts to deescalate Youth A prior to the restraint. The
description is similar to the information in other documents and
information provided by staff interviewed.
MiSACWIS incident report #182050234 dated 4/27/24 and
submitted 4/29/24. This incident report outlines the physical
restraint of Youth A on 4/27/24. The information provided matches
the information in other reports of this incident and information
provided by staff interviewed. A debriefing with Youth A is
documented as having occurred following the restraint. Staff
debriefing is also documented as having occurred within 24-hours.
Pine Rest Christian Mental Health Services Lotus Program –
Restraint Policy dated 6/2023. This document states Restraints
are only used in limited emergencies in which imminent risk of
individual physically harming themselves, staff, or others and
when nonphysical interventions are ineffective. It is also
documented that restraints are only to be initiated by a qualified
staff member who is trained and whose competency is assessed
8

biannually. Prior to the restraint, the qualified staff member is to
identify specific behaviors requiring restraint.
Pine Rest – Mental Health Event Form dated 4/28/24 entered
by Staff 2. This document outlines the physical management of
Youth A on 4/27/24 outlined in the complaint. The description of
the physical management (restraint) of Youth A matches the
information provided during interviews of staff and other written
documents. The list of staff involved matches the information
provided and the medical care provided is outlined.
Change Audit 4/29/24 completed by Staff 7. This document
outlines the changes in the incident reports provided earlier. The
changes included the following.
• Rather than a two-person standing restraint from 2215 to
2223 staff (unidentified) initiated a three-person supine
restraint from 2215 to 2223.
• Youth A verbally and physically threatened a staff to a
detailed description of Youth A not being able to be
verbally de-escalated and swinging at Staff 1.
• Full names of staff rather than last initials.
• Addition of information involving a patient safety event that
reached Youth A.
• Addition of information involves injury details and lists
“scratch”. The addition of identifying the part of the body
with a scratch is now listed.
• Notification of the physician which was not answered in the
past report.
• Unanswered questions involve the likelihood of
reoccurrence (remote), will the incident result in an
increase in the length of stay (unknown), was the incident
associated with National Patient Safety Goals (no), was
the event associated with handoff/handover (no), was
health information implicated in this event (no), was it a
sentinel event (restraint related).
Safety-Care by QBS (Quality Behavioral Solutions) Version 7
1997-2022. This document outlines the following Physical
Management Criteria. First there must be imminent danger of
serious harm to the agitated person or someone else. Second,
there must be no other practical way to avoid that harm without
physical management. Third, the risk of not intervening must be
greater than the risk of intervening. The first type of hold outlined
in this document is the 1-person stability hold which Staff 1
described attempting. Another type is the “floor drop transition”
which must not be initiated by staff but rather provides a way for
9

staff to respond safely if the youth chooses to drop. Staff are to
provide enough support to prevent a hard landing by the youth.
The use of a floor hold (supine) involves the arms in different
positions.
Safety-Care by QBS (Quality Behavioral Solutions) Version 7
1997-2022. 6. Floor Holds. The “supine Stability Hold” is
described using three staff to hold the youth on the ground in a
face up position. Two staff are shown holding the youth by the
youth’s arms with one staff hold an arm. The third staff is shown
holding the legs of the youth.
Email from Administrator 1 to other administrators dated
5/1/24. This email outlines that Staff 1 was placed on paid
administrative leave on Sunday, April 28th, Staff 1 will remain on
paid administrative leave pending the outcome of the special
investigation.
Pine Rest – V3 Basic Employee Event Form dated 4/27/24 for
Staff 1. This document outlines Staff 1 being injured during the
intervention with Youth A on 4/27/24. Staff 1 lists his injuries as
“head injury and stress/psychological impairment”, after
repeatedly being punched in the face and head by Youth A.
Staff 1’s personnel file: Documentation indicates Staff 1 was
hired in October 2023 and there is no disciplinary action.
Documentation in the file indicates Staff 1 completed behavior
management (QBS 8 hours) on 10/20/23 and Orientation on
10/16/23. Staff 1 is current on all training requirements.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, and documents reviewed, Staff 1 restrained Youth A
without following the approved technique when Staff 1 held both of
Youth A’s arms above his head while in a supine position.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered in the aspect of writing the
incident reports following a restraint, so all the information is
consistent and accurate. Also, the facility develop a method of
instructing staff on the process of documenting an incident.
Conclusion Violation Established
10

Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule R 400.4163 Health status assessment; notification;
Section debriefing; reporting.
Description (5) An agency will provide an incident report on a form prescribed by
the department for each incident involving the use of seclusion or
restraint. The initial report shall be submitted to the department within
24 hours of the incident occurring. A final incident report shall be
submitted no later than 72 hours after the incident has occurred.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation During the course of this investigation, it was discovered that the
incident took place on 4/27/24 but the incident report was not
submitted until 4/29/24.
Investigation MiSACWIS incident report #182050234 dated 4/27/24 and
submitted 4/29/24 This incident report outlines the physical
restraint of Youth A on 4/27/24. The information provided matches
the information in other reports of this incident and information
provided by staff interviewed. A debriefing with Youth A is
documented as having occurred following the restraint. Staff
debriefing is also documented as having occurred within 24-hours.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as documents reviewed,
indicate the incident took place on 4/27/24 and not submitted until
4/29/24.
Conclusion Violation Established
11

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
